content: Ingest mulethi to treat a variety of ailments. Mulethi, or licorice, has traditionally been used for arthritis, stomach ailments, and overly oily hair. In addition, it has been clinically show to have some effectiveness for: [1] Heartburn The skin condition eczema Low blood pressure Addison's disease (suppressed adrenal gland functioning) Maintaining blood potassium levels for people undergoing dialysis Increased fertility in women with polycystic ovary syndrome Sore throats and mouth sores Reducing body fat Prostate, breast, colon, liver and lung cancer Ulcers [2] Immune disorders [3] Gargle with a mulethi solution to treat sores and bad breath. Combined 1 tsp (5ml) or mulethi powder in 8 oz. (250ml) of lukewarm water and stir until the powder is completely dissolved. [4] Gargle this solution four to five times a day to help soothe and heal mouth sores. When used for mouth sores, this solution should not be swallowed. [5] Similarly, gargling a solution made with 1/4 cup (60 ml) warm water and 1/2 tsp (2.5 ml) mulethi extract can help reduce or eliminate bad breath. Drink mulethi tea for coughs, sore throat, stomach complaints or menstrual cramps. Combine 1 Tbsp (15 ml) of crushed mulethi root with 2 cups (500 ml) of water in a small saucepan. Simmer the mixture on your stove over low heat for 15-20 minutes. [6] Filter before drinking. Drink the tea while still warm to help treat a cold, cough, or upper respiratory infection. Consume the tea once a day for a month to help heal acid reflux and peptic ulcers. To maximize the benefits of mulethi tea during menstruation, take it once a day starting three days before menstruation. Combine mulethi tea with other herbs to heighten effectiveness. Mulethi is believed to help increase the effectiveness of many other herbs when consumed simultaneously. You can blend mulethi with certain other herbal teas, and the conditions those teas may treat can become even more beneficial. Combine a ¼ cup of mulethi root with a 1-inch (2.5-cm) piece of ginger (sliced) and 2 quarts (2000 ml) of water. Bring to a boil, then lower heat and simmer for 10 minutes. Strain and drink while still warm. This particular blend can be used to treat colds, sore throat, and indigestion. [7] Combine equal parts mulethi, chamomile, and peppermint. Use this mixture in a one-to-five ratio of herbs-to-water and steep over low heat for 10 minutes. Strain and drink as a way of treating indigestion and heartburn. [8] Chew on a piece of mulethi to soothe a sore throat or fight bad breath. Cut off a piece of raw licorice and chew on it for 5 to 15 minutes. Licorice both numbs the throat and acts as a demulcent, coating your throat in a thin layer of mucus that soothes it. [9] Licorice contains anti-bacterial compounds that fight the bacteria that cause cavities and bad breath. [10] Take licorice supplements for a variety of conditions. While teas and rinses are preferred for sore throats, mouth ailments, and indigestion due to their soothing effects, other conditions are best addressed by taking supplements in pill or extract form. Licorice supplements have anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and antiviral effects that make them effective at treating low blood pressure, Addison's disease, infertility due to polycystic ovary syndrome, ulcers, indigestion, cancer (as a supplement), and immune disorders. Use DGL (Deglycyrrhizinated Licorice) if possible. It lacks the chemical glycyrrhizin, which can cause high blood pressure and muscle weakness. [11] The correct dose of non-DGL licorice is 2mg per kg of weight per day. WARNING: If your licorice is not DGL, do not take more than 100mg/day – approximately 1 ml of extract. Licorice overdose results in an excess of the hormone aldosterone, which can lead to muscle weakness, headaches, and high blood pressure. Be sure your licorice product contains actual licorice. In the U.S., it is common to use anise oil instead of licorice in many "licorice" products. Note which conditions topical treatment might help. The topical application of mulethi is typically used to treat various skin conditions like eczema, but it can also be used to combat internal conditions with external manifestations (like cold sores), to improve one's overall energy, to treat melasma and lighten skin, and even to reduce the thickness of subcutaneous fat. Make a mulethi root salve. Place 2 tbsp (30 ml) of mulethi root in 6 cups (1500 ml) of water. Let it simmer over medium-low heat on the stove for 40 minutes. Strain and allow to cool. You can apply the resulting salve directly to the skin with a cotton pad. Apply the licorice salve directly to irritated skin such as a rash or eczema. [12] Dab the salve on dark patches of skin once a day before bed to treat melasma. [13] Rub the salve on thighs, arms, or other areas with cellulite to reduce the thickness of subcutaneous fat. Soak in a mild mulethi solution to reduce fatigue and treat low blood pressure. Combine 3/4 cup (180 ml) crushed mulethi root and 4 cups (1 L) of warm water. Allow the mixture to rest for two to three hours, then boil it for 5 minutes. Mix the still hot solution into your bathwater and soak for 20-30 minutes. [14] Make a paste with mulethi powder to fight acne, hair loss, or calluses. Purchase licorice powder, or grind down enough dried mulethi root to produce 1 Tbsp (15 ml). Combine this with 1/2 to 1 cup (125 to 250 ml) of cold milk, stirring well to form a thin paste. [15] Add 1 tsp of honey to help fight acne. Honey has proven antimicrobial and healing properties. [16] Add 1/4 tsp (1.25 ml) of saffron to this paste and apply it to your scalp to help fight against hair loss. Add 1 tsp (5 ml) of olive oil instead of milk for a paste that will help to soften corns and calluses. Use mulethi extract for cold sores or genital herpes. You can use the extract much as you would the paste or salve. However, it is better for more focused applications, like cold sores. If you are going to used it over a broad area of skin, consider first diluting the extract. The glycyrrhizin in licorice extract has been shown to stop the reproduction of the virus that causes cold sores and genital herpes. Apply it directly to the sores twice a day. [17] Use mulethi to add flavor to a variety of dishes. Licorice, whether in root form or as a powder, can add notes of fennel and anise to any dish. You can use it for sweets, savories, sauces, and more. Make licorice syrup. A syrup made using boiled licorice roots can be poured over ice cream, cookies, or any other dessert to add a sweet licorice flavor. To make the syrup: [18] Peel and chop the root. Place in a pot, cover with water, and simmer for at least an hour. Add sugar – ¼ cup sugar per 4 cups of liquid. Bring to a simmer until sugar dissolves. Put in jars while still very hot. Steep licorice roots to add flavor to teas, syrups, sauces, and custards. Add the root to the tea, syrup, sauce, or custard you are preparing and heat. Let it steep for at least 10 minutes – the longer the more intense the flavor. Remove the root before serving. [19] Add flavor to sugar or salt cures. Licorice roots can be used a lot like vanilla pods to add subtle flavor to dried goods. Bury some in your sugar jar, or add the roots to salt and use it in cookies and puddings, or sprinkled on seafood, roasted carrots, or sweet potatoes. [20] Flavor your coffee with licorice. You can simply use a licorice root to stir your coffee (for a stronger flavor let it steep for a bit). Or for an even more powerful taste, add a dash of licorice powder to your cup of joe. [21] Include a pinch of powdered licorice in savory dishes. You can add powdered licorice straight to recipes. It works particularly well in meat rubs, and pairs well with pigeon, duck, quail, pork, and lamb. [22] Let licorice stand out in sweets. Licorice is a powerful flavor, so you'll want to make it the star ingredient in sweets. Try stirring it into batters or custards, or creating dishes that let it shine, like licorice ice cream or licorice panna cotta. [23] For a list of some great licorice-flavored sweets, check out /2013/04/15/licorice-flavored-recipes-desserts_n_3084184.html .

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Mulethi">How to Use Mulethi</a></h1>
<div class="" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="staff_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		wikiHow Staff</a><span class="ss_pipe">|</span><a class="expert_coauthor_link ss_review" href="#article_info_section">Reader-Approved</a>
<span class="ss_pipe">|</span><a href="#references">24 References</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Taking_Mulethi_Orally_to_Treat_Medical_Conditions_sub" id="">Taking Mulethi Orally to Treat Medical Conditions</a>

<a class="" href="#" id="summary_toc">Article Summary</a>

</p>
<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by our trained team of editors and researchers who validated it for accuracy and comprehensiveness. Together, they cited information from <a href="#references">24 references</a>. wikiHow's <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers#wikihow%20content%20team%20managers">Content Management Team</a> carefully monitors the work from our editorial staff to ensure that each article meets our high standards.<br/><br/>wikiHow marks an article as reader-approved once it receives enough positive feedback. This article has over 151,068 views and 86% of readers who voted found it helpful, earning it our reader-approved status.
		<a class="sp_learn_more_link" href="/wikiHow:About-wikiHow#Why_should_you_choose_wikiHow_first.3F_sub">Learn more...</a>
</div>
</div>
<p>Mulethi, more commonly known as licorice, is both a popular herbal supplement used to treat a variety of medical conditions, and an ingredient long popular in Asian and Middle Eastern cooking. Whether taken orally or used topically it has a variety of health benefits, some of which are traditional and some clinically proven, so long as it is taken in small doses for short periods of time. As an ingredient, it adds an herby anise and fennel flavor that work well in drinks, sweets, and savories alike.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Taking_Mulethi_Orally_to_Treat_Medical_Conditions_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Taking_Mulethi_Orally_to_Treat_Medical_Conditions">Taking Mulethi Orally to Treat Medical Conditions</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-1-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-1-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/16/Use-Mulethi-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_5e2d49f597" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5e2d49f597')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/16/Use-Mulethi-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Ingest mulethi to treat a variety of ailments.</b> Mulethi, or licorice, has traditionally been used for arthritis, stomach ailments, and overly oily hair. In addition, it has been clinically show to have some effectiveness for:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Heartburn</li>
<li>The skin condition eczema</li>
<li>Low blood pressure</li>
<li>Addison's disease (suppressed adrenal gland functioning)</li>
<li>Maintaining blood potassium levels for people undergoing dialysis</li>
<li>Increased fertility in women with polycystic ovary syndrome</li>
<li>Sore throats and mouth sores</li>
<li>Reducing body fat</li>
<li>Prostate, breast, colon, liver and lung cancer</li>
<li>Ulcers<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Immune disorders<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-2-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-2-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Use-Mulethi-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_d65c6d528b" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d65c6d528b')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Use-Mulethi-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Gargle with a mulethi solution to treat sores and bad breath.</b> Combined 1 tsp (5ml) or mulethi powder in 8 oz. (250ml) of lukewarm water and stir until the powder is completely dissolved.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Gargle this solution four to five times a day to help soothe and heal mouth sores. When used for mouth sores, this solution should not be swallowed.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Similarly, gargling a solution made with 1/4 cup (60 ml) warm water and 1/2 tsp (2.5 ml) mulethi extract can help reduce or eliminate bad breath.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-3-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-3-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Use-Mulethi-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_9ed95e67b0" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9ed95e67b0')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Use-Mulethi-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Drink mulethi tea for coughs, sore throat, stomach complaints or menstrual cramps.</b> Combine 1 Tbsp (15 ml) of crushed mulethi root with 2 cups (500 ml) of water in a small saucepan. Simmer the mixture on your stove over low heat for 15-20 minutes.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup> Filter before drinking.

<ul>
<li>Drink the tea while still warm to help treat a cold, cough, or upper respiratory infection.</li>
<li>Consume the tea once a day for a month to help heal acid reflux and peptic ulcers.</li>
<li>To maximize the benefits of mulethi tea during menstruation, take it once a day starting three days before menstruation.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-4-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-4-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Use-Mulethi-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_a7ceacb62f" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a7ceacb62f')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Use-Mulethi-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Combine mulethi tea with other herbs to heighten effectiveness.</b> Mulethi is believed to help increase the effectiveness of many other herbs when consumed simultaneously. You can blend mulethi with certain other herbal teas, and the conditions those teas may treat can become even more beneficial.

<ul>
<li>Combine a ¼ cup of mulethi root with a 1-inch (2.5-cm) piece of ginger (sliced) and 2 quarts (2000 ml) of water. Bring to a boil, then lower heat and simmer for 10 minutes. Strain and drink while still warm. This particular blend can be used to treat colds, sore throat, and indigestion.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Combine equal parts mulethi, chamomile, and peppermint. Use this mixture in a one-to-five ratio of herbs-to-water and steep over low heat for 10 minutes. Strain and drink as a way of treating indigestion and heartburn.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-5-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-5-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/22/Use-Mulethi-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_3aaa4c781a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3aaa4c781a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/22/Use-Mulethi-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Chew on a piece of mulethi to soothe a sore throat or fight bad breath.</b> Cut off a piece of raw licorice and chew on it for 5 to 15 minutes.

<ul>
<li>Licorice both numbs the throat and acts as a demulcent, coating your throat in a thin layer of mucus that soothes it.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Licorice contains anti-bacterial compounds that fight the bacteria that cause cavities and bad breath.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-6-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-6-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Use-Mulethi-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_81ff343250" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_81ff343250')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Use-Mulethi-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Take licorice supplements for a variety of conditions.</b> While teas and rinses are preferred for sore throats, mouth ailments, and indigestion due to their soothing effects, other conditions are best addressed by taking supplements in pill or extract form. Licorice supplements have anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and antiviral effects that make them effective at treating low blood pressure, Addison's disease, infertility due to polycystic ovary syndrome, ulcers, indigestion, cancer (as a supplement), and immune disorders.

<ul>
<li>Use DGL (Deglycyrrhizinated Licorice) if possible. It lacks the chemical glycyrrhizin, which can cause high blood pressure and muscle weakness.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>The correct dose of non-DGL licorice is 2mg per kg of weight per day.</li>
<li>WARNING: If your licorice is not DGL, do not take more than 100mg/day – approximately 1 ml of extract. Licorice overdose results in an excess of the hormone aldosterone, which can lead to muscle weakness, headaches, and high blood pressure.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-7-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-7-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Use-Mulethi-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_f63e78fc01" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f63e78fc01')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Use-Mulethi-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Be sure your licorice product contains actual licorice.</b> In the U.S., it is common to use anise oil instead of licorice in many "licorice" products.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('methodad'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Using_Mulethi_Topically_for_Skin_Ailments_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Using_Mulethi_Topically_for_Skin_Ailments">Using Mulethi Topically for Skin Ailments</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-8-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-8-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Use-Mulethi-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-8-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_e72e32d143" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e72e32d143')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Use-Mulethi-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-8-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Note which conditions topical treatment might help.</b> The topical application of mulethi is typically used to treat various skin conditions like eczema, but it can also be used to combat internal conditions with external manifestations (like cold sores), to improve one's overall energy, to treat melasma and lighten skin, and even to reduce the thickness of subcutaneous fat.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-9-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-9-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f9/Use-Mulethi-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-9-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_9604339019" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9604339019')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f9/Use-Mulethi-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-9-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Make a mulethi root salve.</b> Place 2 tbsp (30 ml) of mulethi root in 6 cups (1500 ml) of water. Let it simmer over medium-low heat on the stove for 40 minutes. Strain and allow to cool. You can apply the resulting salve directly to the skin with a cotton pad.

<ul>
<li>Apply the licorice salve directly to irritated skin such as a rash or eczema.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Dab the salve on dark patches of skin once a day before bed to treat melasma.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Rub the salve on thighs, arms, or other areas with cellulite to reduce the thickness of subcutaneous fat.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-10-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-10-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Use-Mulethi-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_71f4bcab59" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_71f4bcab59')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Use-Mulethi-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Soak in a mild mulethi solution to reduce fatigue and treat low blood pressure.</b> Combine 3/4 cup (180 ml) crushed mulethi root and 4 cups (1 L) of warm water. Allow the mixture to rest for two to three hours, then boil it for 5 minutes. Mix the still hot solution into your bathwater and soak for 20-30 minutes.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-11-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-11-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6e/Use-Mulethi-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_86c187a575" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_86c187a575')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6e/Use-Mulethi-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Make a paste with mulethi powder to fight acne, hair loss, or calluses.</b> Purchase licorice powder, or grind down enough dried mulethi root to produce 1 Tbsp (15 ml). Combine this with 1/2 to 1 cup (125 to 250 ml) of cold milk, stirring well to form a thin paste.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Add 1 tsp of honey to help fight acne. Honey has proven antimicrobial and healing properties.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Add 1/4 tsp (1.25 ml) of saffron to this paste and apply it to your scalp to help fight against hair loss.</li>
<li>Add 1 tsp (5 ml) of olive oil instead of milk for a paste that will help to soften corns and calluses.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-12-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-12-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Use-Mulethi-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-12-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_9f05724ec2" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9f05724ec2')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Use-Mulethi-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-12-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use mulethi extract for cold sores or genital herpes.</b> You can use the extract much as you would the paste or salve. However, it is better for more focused applications, like cold sores. If you are going to used it over a broad area of skin, consider first diluting the extract.

<ul>
<li>The glycyrrhizin in licorice extract has been shown to stop the reproduction of the virus that causes cold sores and genital herpes. Apply it directly to the sores twice a day.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Cooking_with_Mulethi_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Cooking_with_Mulethi">Cooking with Mulethi</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-13-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-13-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/46/Use-Mulethi-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-13-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_0fe5f6d8ff" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0fe5f6d8ff')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/46/Use-Mulethi-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-13-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use mulethi to add flavor to a variety of dishes.</b> Licorice, whether in root form or as a powder, can add notes of fennel and anise to any dish. You can use it for sweets, savories, sauces, and more.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-14-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-14-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f9/Use-Mulethi-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-14-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_892095ed2a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_892095ed2a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f9/Use-Mulethi-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-14-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Make licorice syrup.</b> A syrup made using boiled licorice roots can be poured over ice cream, cookies, or any other dessert to add a sweet licorice flavor. To make the syrup:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 18" class="reference" id="_ref-18"><a href="#_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Peel and chop the root.</li>
<li>Place in a pot, cover with water, and simmer for at least an hour.</li>
<li>Add sugar – ¼ cup sugar per 4 cups of liquid. Bring to a simmer until sugar dissolves.</li>
<li>Put in jars while still very hot.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-15-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-15-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Use-Mulethi-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-15-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_79deac8e52" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_79deac8e52')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Use-Mulethi-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-15-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Steep licorice roots to add flavor to teas, syrups, sauces, and custards.</b> Add the root to the tea, syrup, sauce, or custard you are preparing and heat. Let it steep for at least 10 minutes – the longer the more intense the flavor. Remove the root before serving.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 19" class="reference" id="_ref-19"><a href="#_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-16-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-16-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Use-Mulethi-Step-16-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-16-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_5b5d38f339" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5b5d38f339')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Use-Mulethi-Step-16-Version-2.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-16-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Add flavor to sugar or salt cures.</b> Licorice roots can be used a lot like vanilla pods to add subtle flavor to dried goods. Bury some in your sugar jar, or add the roots to salt and use it in cookies and puddings, or sprinkled on seafood, roasted carrots, or sweet potatoes.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 20" class="reference" id="_ref-20"><a href="#_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-17.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-17.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/Use-Mulethi-Step-17.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-17.jpg" height="546" id="img_ed03a88445" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ed03a88445')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/Use-Mulethi-Step-17.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-17.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Flavor your coffee with licorice.</b> You can simply use a licorice root to stir your coffee (for a stronger flavor let it steep for a bit). Or for an even more powerful taste, add a dash of licorice powder to your cup of joe.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 21" class="reference" id="_ref-21"><a href="#_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-18.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-18.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/Use-Mulethi-Step-18.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-18.jpg" height="546" id="img_54257fb61d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_54257fb61d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/Use-Mulethi-Step-18.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-18.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Include a pinch of powdered licorice in savory dishes.</b> You can add powdered licorice straight to recipes. It works particularly well in meat rubs, and pairs well with pigeon, duck, quail, pork, and lamb.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 22" class="reference" id="_ref-22"><a href="#_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-19.jpg?ajax=true&aid=5227429" href="#/Image:Use-Mulethi-Step-19.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 19" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/Use-Mulethi-Step-19.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-19.jpg" height="546" id="img_63ee55c897" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_63ee55c897')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Mulethi Step 19" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/Use-Mulethi-Step-19.jpg/aid5227429-v4-728px-Use-Mulethi-Step-19.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Let licorice stand out in sweets.</b> Licorice is a powerful flavor, so you'll want to make it the star ingredient in sweets. Try stirring it into batters or custards, or creating dishes that let it shine, like licorice ice cream or licorice panna cotta.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 23" class="reference" id="_ref-23"><a href="#_note-23">[23]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>For a list of some great licorice-flavored sweets, check out <a class="external free" href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/15/licorice-flavored-recipes-desserts_n_3084184.html" rel="nofollow">http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/15/licorice-flavored-recipes-desserts_n_3084184.html</a>.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="5227429" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>
<a id="qa_add_curated_question">Add New Question</a>
<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="87935" data-caid="88808" data-cqid="87952" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="595991" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="105309" data-votes_down="6" data-votes_up="11">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Can mulethi help me get fair skin?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_expert_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" style="background-image: url(/images/e/ef/Zora-Degrandpre.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_expert_name">
<a class="sp_namelink" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" target="_blank">Zora Degrandpre, ND</a><br/>
	Naturopathic Doctor
</div>
Dr. Degrandpre is a licensed Naturopathic Physician in Washington. She received her ND from the National College of Natural Medicine in 2007.
</div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<a class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" style="background-image: url(/images/e/ef/Zora-Degrandpre.jpg)" target="_blank">
</a>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name">
<a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=zoradegrandpre%2Cnd#zoradegrandpre%2Cnd" target="_blank">Zora Degrandpre, ND</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_user_title">Naturopathic Doctor</div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Expert Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Yes, mulethi or licorice is an anti-inflammatory herb and can be used on the skin to reduce the inflammation from acne, eczema and skin rashes.  Mulethi has also been used to lighten darker patches on the skin such as melasma, a darkening of facial skin during pregnancy.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>6</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>11</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="273382" data-caid="274255" data-cqid="273399" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1226144" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="6">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">How long do I take mulethi powder?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">As long as possible. It does not has any side effects, and is a very good product for skin, regulating blood pressure, sore throat, etc.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>0</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>6</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="288358" data-caid="289231" data-cqid="288375" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="994837" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="2" data-votes_up="3">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Can this cure diabetes?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">There is no cure for diabetes, but mulethi in conjunction with a healthy diet and exercise can help you control your diabetes.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>

<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Can I remove my private part hair in Mulethi powder?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">

</div>

<div class="qa_answer answer">Yes. You can mix the Mulethi powder with some water so it's a paste, then rub it on your private part hair and leave it for about 30 minutes. The hair should come off with water. </div>

<div class="section warnings sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Warnings">Warnings</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="warnings">
<ul>
<li>Licorice interacts with many medications. Always consult your doctor before taking mulethi for medicinal purposes.</li>
<li>Do not take mulethi for more than four weeks unless instructed otherwise by your doctor. Consuming 100mg or more for prolonged periods can drastically increase blood pressure and lower potassium levels in otherwise healthy people. If you suffer from heart disease, kidney disease, or high blood pressure, even small amounts can cause complications.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 24" class="reference" id="_ref-24"><a href="#_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Do not take mulethi during pregnancy. High consumption can cause miscarriage or early delivery. Little is known about the effects of mulethi during nursing, so it is recommended that you avoid it during this stage, as well.</li>
<li>Stop taking mulethi at least two weeks before a scheduled surgery since it can affect your body's blood pressure control.</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<div id="summary_wrapper"><div id="summary_text">
<h2>Article Summary<a href="#" id="summary_close">X</a>
</h2>
<p>To use mulethi, which is also called licorice, try making a tea with some of the crushed root to help with coughs, stomach aches, or sore throats. You can also take mulethi as a dietary supplement to treat low blood pressure, ulcers, and immune disorders, since it has antiviral and antioxidant properties. Alternatively, add it to recipes where you’d like a strong licorice flavor. For example, try steeping a piece of mulethi root in tea or adding powdered mulethi to spice rubs. <span id="summary_last_sentence">For tips on how to make your own mulethi syrup to add to drinks and recipes, read on!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>

title: How to Use Mulethi
content_html:
Ingest mulethi to treat a variety of ailments. Mulethi, or licorice, has traditionally been used for arthritis, stomach ailments, and overly oily hair. In addition, it has been clinically show to have some effectiveness for:[1]
  • Heartburn
  • The skin condition eczema
  • Low blood pressure
  • Addison's disease (suppressed adrenal gland functioning)
  • Maintaining blood potassium levels for people undergoing dialysis
  • Increased fertility in women with polycystic ovary syndrome
  • Sore throats and mouth sores
  • Reducing body fat
  • Prostate, breast, colon, liver and lung cancer
  • Ulcers[2]
  • Immune disorders[3]
Gargle with a mulethi solution to treat sores and bad breath. Combined 1 tsp (5ml) or mulethi powder in 8 oz. (250ml) of lukewarm water and stir until the powder is completely dissolved.[4]
  • Gargle this solution four to five times a day to help soothe and heal mouth sores. When used for mouth sores, this solution should not be swallowed.[5]
  • Similarly, gargling a solution made with 1/4 cup (60 ml) warm water and 1/2 tsp (2.5 ml) mulethi extract can help reduce or eliminate bad breath.
Drink mulethi tea for coughs, sore throat, stomach complaints or menstrual cramps. Combine 1 Tbsp (15 ml) of crushed mulethi root with 2 cups (500 ml) of water in a small saucepan. Simmer the mixture on your stove over low heat for 15-20 minutes.[6] Filter before drinking.
  • Drink the tea while still warm to help treat a cold, cough, or upper respiratory infection.
  • Consume the tea once a day for a month to help heal acid reflux and peptic ulcers.
  • To maximize the benefits of mulethi tea during menstruation, take it once a day starting three days before menstruation.
Combine mulethi tea with other herbs to heighten effectiveness. Mulethi is believed to help increase the effectiveness of many other herbs when consumed simultaneously. You can blend mulethi with certain other herbal teas, and the conditions those teas may treat can become even more beneficial.
  • Combine a ¼ cup of mulethi root with a 1-inch (2.5-cm) piece of ginger (sliced) and 2 quarts (2000 ml) of water. Bring to a boil, then lower heat and simmer for 10 minutes. Strain and drink while still warm. This particular blend can be used to treat colds, sore throat, and indigestion.[7]
  • Combine equal parts mulethi, chamomile, and peppermint. Use this mixture in a one-to-five ratio of herbs-to-water and steep over low heat for 10 minutes. Strain and drink as a way of treating indigestion and heartburn.[8]
Chew on a piece of mulethi to soothe a sore throat or fight bad breath. Cut off a piece of raw licorice and chew on it for 5 to 15 minutes.
  • Licorice both numbs the throat and acts as a demulcent, coating your throat in a thin layer of mucus that soothes it.[9]
  • Licorice contains anti-bacterial compounds that fight the bacteria that cause cavities and bad breath.[10]
Take licorice supplements for a variety of conditions. While teas and rinses are preferred for sore throats, mouth ailments, and indigestion due to their soothing effects, other conditions are best addressed by taking supplements in pill or extract form. Licorice supplements have anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and antiviral effects that make them effective at treating low blood pressure, Addison's disease, infertility due to polycystic ovary syndrome, ulcers, indigestion, cancer (as a supplement), and immune disorders.
  • Use DGL (Deglycyrrhizinated Licorice) if possible. It lacks the chemical glycyrrhizin, which can cause high blood pressure and muscle weakness.[11]
  • The correct dose of non-DGL licorice is 2mg per kg of weight per day.
  • WARNING: If your licorice is not DGL, do not take more than 100mg/day – approximately 1 ml of extract. Licorice overdose results in an excess of the hormone aldosterone, which can lead to muscle weakness, headaches, and high blood pressure.
Be sure your licorice product contains actual licorice. In the U.S., it is common to use anise oil instead of licorice in many "licorice" products.
Note which conditions topical treatment might help. The topical application of mulethi is typically used to treat various skin conditions like eczema, but it can also be used to combat internal conditions with external manifestations (like cold sores), to improve one's overall energy, to treat melasma and lighten skin, and even to reduce the thickness of subcutaneous fat.
Make a mulethi root salve. Place 2 tbsp (30 ml) of mulethi root in 6 cups (1500 ml) of water. Let it simmer over medium-low heat on the stove for 40 minutes. Strain and allow to cool. You can apply the resulting salve directly to the skin with a cotton pad.
  • Apply the licorice salve directly to irritated skin such as a rash or eczema.[12]
  • Dab the salve on dark patches of skin once a day before bed to treat melasma.[13]
  • Rub the salve on thighs, arms, or other areas with cellulite to reduce the thickness of subcutaneous fat.
Soak in a mild mulethi solution to reduce fatigue and treat low blood pressure. Combine 3/4 cup (180 ml) crushed mulethi root and 4 cups (1 L) of warm water. Allow the mixture to rest for two to three hours, then boil it for 5 minutes. Mix the still hot solution into your bathwater and soak for 20-30 minutes.[14]
Make a paste with mulethi powder to fight acne, hair loss, or calluses. Purchase licorice powder, or grind down enough dried mulethi root to produce 1 Tbsp (15 ml). Combine this with 1/2 to 1 cup (125 to 250 ml) of cold milk, stirring well to form a thin paste.[15]
  • Add 1 tsp of honey to help fight acne. Honey has proven antimicrobial and healing properties.[16]
  • Add 1/4 tsp (1.25 ml) of saffron to this paste and apply it to your scalp to help fight against hair loss.
  • Add 1 tsp (5 ml) of olive oil instead of milk for a paste that will help to soften corns and calluses.
Use mulethi extract for cold sores or genital herpes. You can use the extract much as you would the paste or salve. However, it is better for more focused applications, like cold sores. If you are going to used it over a broad area of skin, consider first diluting the extract.
  • The glycyrrhizin in licorice extract has been shown to stop the reproduction of the virus that causes cold sores and genital herpes. Apply it directly to the sores twice a day.[17]
Use mulethi to add flavor to a variety of dishes. Licorice, whether in root form or as a powder, can add notes of fennel and anise to any dish. You can use it for sweets, savories, sauces, and more.
Make licorice syrup. A syrup made using boiled licorice roots can be poured over ice cream, cookies, or any other dessert to add a sweet licorice flavor. To make the syrup:[18]
  • Peel and chop the root.
  • Place in a pot, cover with water, and simmer for at least an hour.
  • Add sugar – ¼ cup sugar per 4 cups of liquid. Bring to a simmer until sugar dissolves.
  • Put in jars while still very hot.
Steep licorice roots to add flavor to teas, syrups, sauces, and custards. Add the root to the tea, syrup, sauce, or custard you are preparing and heat. Let it steep for at least 10 minutes – the longer the more intense the flavor. Remove the root before serving.[19]
Add flavor to sugar or salt cures. Licorice roots can be used a lot like vanilla pods to add subtle flavor to dried goods. Bury some in your sugar jar, or add the roots to salt and use it in cookies and puddings, or sprinkled on seafood, roasted carrots, or sweet potatoes.[20]
Flavor your coffee with licorice. You can simply use a licorice root to stir your coffee (for a stronger flavor let it steep for a bit). Or for an even more powerful taste, add a dash of licorice powder to your cup of joe.[21]
Include a pinch of powdered licorice in savory dishes. You can add powdered licorice straight to recipes. It works particularly well in meat rubs, and pairs well with pigeon, duck, quail, pork, and lamb.[22]
Let licorice stand out in sweets. Licorice is a powerful flavor, so you'll want to make it the star ingredient in sweets. Try stirring it into batters or custards, or creating dishes that let it shine, like licorice ice cream or licorice panna cotta.[23]
  • For a list of some great licorice-flavored sweets, check out http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/15/licorice-flavored-recipes-desserts_n_3084184.html.
